Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Situation2: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Story: I stared at the clock, my hands still damp from scrubbing the kitchen counters. The dust on the living room shelves was thicker than usual, and I knew if I didn’t tackle it today, it would only get worse. But my mentor’s office hours had just started, and I’d promised myself I’d make the most of every opportunity to learn from her. She always emphasized respecting her time, and I didn’t want to show up late or distracted. Yet, the mess nagged at me—if I left it, I’d be failing in my responsibility as a cleaner, letting standards slip. My mind raced between the image of my mentor waiting, perhaps disappointed by my absence, and the growing mess that would reflect poorly on my work ethic. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
